benchmark_details.name: CTSES (Composite Test Similarity Evaluation Score)
benchmark_details.overview: CTSES is a behavior-preserving, readability-aware metric specifically tailored to evaluate test refactoring. It combines CodeBLEU, METEOR, and ROUGE-L into a weighted composite metric that balances syntactic accuracy, lexical clarity, and structural alignment.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a comprehensive assessment of the quality of refactored unit tests leveraging Large Language Models.

data.source: Over 5,000 unit tests automatically refactored by GPT-4o and Mistral-Large-2407 using two established Java benchmarks: Defects4J and SF110.
data.annotation: Tests were refactored using Chain-of-Thought prompting.

methodology.calculation: CTSES is calculated as a weighted linear combination of CodeBLEU, METEOR, and ROUGE-L: CTSES = α·CodeBLEU + β·METEOR + γ·ROUGE-L.
methodology.interpretation: Higher CTSES scores indicate better alignment with developer expectations regarding readability, structural quality, and behavioral consistency.
methodology.validation: Empirical validation is performed against baseline similarity metrics.
